https://carsandbids.com/auctions/r4BXLEL.dougs_take: Now this is cool! We didn't get the original Impreza WRX STI in the United States, so it's hard to find – and this example looks like a good one. Subaru released the first WRX in Japan in 1992. Offered as a sedan and a little later as a wagon, the WRX (World Rally eXperimental) benefited from the lessons the Japanese firm learned while racing the Legacy in international rally events. https://carsandbids.com/auctions/9WLqyyx.auction_subtitle: NO RESERVE Rare Hot Hatchback, 5-Speed Manual, Lotus-Tuned Suspension System
https://carsandbids.com/auctions/9WLqyyx.dougs_take: WOW – how cool is this? Hot hatches were hugely popular in the 1980s, but the Isuzu I-Mark RS Turbo was one of the more obscure entries into the segment – this is the first one that we've listed since launching Cars & Bids nearly three years ago! It looks like it's been well-kept: it's finished in a head-turning shade of red, it's very nearly unmodified, and it boasts reasonable mileage for a 35-year-old car. The accident-free Carfax report is another big benefit, and I think the body kit suits the boxy design pretty well. This is the kind of car that's sure to spark a conversation everywhere you go – be prepared to answer questions like "What's an I-Mark?" and "What does Lotus have to do with it?" every time you get gas. No reserve should make this a very exciting auction to watch and participate in.
auction_highlights: The attached Carfax history report starts in 2006 and lists no accidents since, though it contains several gaps.

Factory equipment includes a Lotus-tuned suspension system, an RS Turbo-specific body kit, cloth upholstery, Recaro front seats, manual windows, and air conditioning. The only modification reported by the selling dealer is a set of 14-inch Enkei wheels.

The second-generation Isuzu I-Mark went on sale for the 1985 model year. Designed by Giorgetto Giugiaro, it was developed primarily as a cheap, basic form of transportation that could be sold globally, but Isuzu saw an opportunity to turn the hatchback variant into an alternative to the Volkswagen GTI. Launched for 1987, the RS Turbo received a turbocharged engine and a sportier suspension system tuned by Lotus. Production ended after 1989.
Power comes from a 1.5-liter turbocharged 4-cylinder engine, rated at 110 horsepower and 120 lb-ft of torque. It spins the front wheels via a 5-speed manual transmission.

Released for the 1989 model year, the "E34"-generation 5 Series deserves a tremendous amount of credit for positioning BMW as a true alternative to Mercedes-Benz. It remained as engaging to drive as its predecessor, the E28, but it was bigger in every direction, and it crucially moved towards the luxury side of the sport sedan scale. https://carsandbids.com/auctions/3gxzn2e.dougs_take: The Shelby GT500 is the most thrilling version of the S197 Mustang, boasting shocking performance, a hugely powerful supercharged V8, and a mandatory 6-speed manual transmission. This Super Snake also boasts just 14,000 miles on the odometer, and it has some excellent equipment and a lot of special details, further adding to the appeal. Called S197 internally, the 5th-generation Mustang launched for 2005 with a heritage-laced design, a new platform, and an available 24-valve V8 engine. Extending the wheelbase gave the Mustang a much more compliant ride than its predecessor. 2010 brought a thorough mid-cycle update that applied to all variants (including the mighty GT500), and production ended in 2014.

The 2013 Ford Mustang Shelby GT500 was the first factory Mustang to achieve a top speed of over 200 mph, stopping at 202 mph. This is also the last Shelby GT500 variant of the S197 generation Mustang, featuring many chassis upgrades over its predecessor along with the final styling revisions introduced during the 2013 model year.

Power comes from a 5.8-liter Trinity supercharged V8 engine, rated at 622 horsepower and 631 lb-ft of torque in stock form. Output is sent to the rear wheels via a 6-speed manual transmission.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/3owWzZD.dougs_take: I think the 993 is one of the best Porsche 911 models produced, as it offers amazing handling along with a small size and powerful flat-6 – all of which add up to a fantastic analog driving experience you just can't get in a modern car. This particular 911 is special, however, as it's been modified to resemble a rare Carrera RS. It features a flat-6 engine that's been bored out to 3.8 liters, and it touts some great upgrades intended to improve its performance and its look – including a DME upgrade, 993 Turbo brake rotors and calipers, an aftermarket exhaust system, Bilstein suspension, an RS-style front splitter, a GT2-style rear spoiler, 18-inch RS-style wheels, and an RS-style interior. This 993 also benefits from a comprehensive engine overhaul in July 2022 that totaled over $32,000! On top of all that, this 911 is offered with a clean, accident-free Carfax report for added buyer assurance.

Service documentation pictured in the gallery shows that this 911 had the timing chains, timing chain rails, rod bearings, gaskets, valves, and other components replaced in July 2022 at 96,022 miles.

The 993 911 was sold for the 1995 to 1998 model years and represented the last – and most powerful – generation of air-cooled 911. Available as a coupe, cabriolet, and Targa, and with rear- or all-wheel drive, the 993 was an evolution of the 964 it replaced, with a more modern look and redesigned rear suspension system.

Power comes from a 3.6-liter air-cooled flat-6, rated at 282 horsepower and 243 lb-ft of torque when left stock. This engine may be making more power as a result of being bored out to 3.8-liters and the modifications, though a dyno sheet is not included. Output is sent to the rear wheels via a 6-Speed manual transmission.

This particular Superleggera is especially desirable, as it has only 2,200 miles and basically no modifications – and it’s finished in the stealthy and very fitting Nero Noctis. It also boasts some great factory equipment, including a LOT of exterior carbon fiber trim, a suspension lift system, and carbon ceramic brakes – and it touts a clean, accident-free Carfax report showing ownership mostly in warm-weather California, further adding to the appeal. I’m thrilled to see this Superleggera on Cars & Bids, and I'm certain the next owner will have a giant smile behind the wheel!

The Gallardo Superleggera is the hardest-hitting version of the baby Lambo thanks to a carbon fiber diet that trimmed 126 pounds off North American models. At the same time, the sensational 5.0-liter V10 also gained some extra horsepower, further improving the power-to-weight ratio. Lamborghini ended up making a total of 618 examples worldwide, according to third-party sources.

Launched for 2004, the Gallardo filled a gap in the Lamborghini range that had remained empty for over a decade. It was smaller and more affordable than the V12-powered Murciélago, so it made the brand accessible to a wider target audience and landed in a segment dominated by arch-nemesis Ferrari. With sharp lines and a sonorous V10 engine, the Gallardo remained in production until 2014, when it was replaced by the Huracán. It retired as the best-selling member of the Lamborghini range to date.
Power comes from a 5.0-liter V10, rated at 523 horsepower and 376 lb-ft of torque. Output is sent to all 4 wheels via a 6-speed “E-Gear” automated manual transmission.
